name: General Knowledge 8 Quiz for Experts | Mixed 25 Questions

questions.text: Salty seas and oceans cover what percentage of the Earth's surface?
questions.explanation:
70 per cent.

	The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean in the world. It covers about 33 percent of the Earth's surface containing more than 50 percent of the Earth's seawater.

questions.text: Who is the arch rival of Popeye the sailorman?
questions.explanation: Bluto.

questions.text: Name the crocodile in Disney's 'Peter Pan'?
questions.explanation:
Tick-tock.

	In a fierce battle Peter Pan had cut off Captain Hook's hand and the hungry crocodile had eaten the pirate's hand. He had enjoyed his meal so much that he now followed Captain Hook everywhere.

questions.text: In the Old Testament, who was the first son of Adam and Eve?
questions.explanation:
Cain.

	Cain killed his younger brother Abel as God accepted Abel's offering in preference to Cain's. The story is recounted in Genesis 4.

questions.text: 'Porridge' was a popular television programme starring Ronnie Barker set in which prison?
questions.explanation:
Slade.

	HM Slade Prison was set in darkest Cumbria (north-west England). Ronnie Barker played the character role of Norman Stanley Fletcher. The opening credits of the sitcom began 'Norman Stanley Fletcher ... you are an habitual criminal who accepts arrest as an occupational hazard and presumably accepts imprisonment in the same casual manner ... '

questions.text: What was the name of the artist who recently painted a controversial portrait of Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain?
questions.explanation:
Lucian Freud.

	Lucian Freud is a British painter born in Germany and is the grandson of Austrian psychoanalyst and physician, Sigmund Freud.

questions.text: Who of the following did not feature in the movie 'Jaws' (1975)?
questions.explanation:
Ray Milland.

	Roy Scheider played Police Chief Brody, Richard Dreyfuss played ichthyologist Hooper and Robert Shaw played old salt Quint.

questions.text: Bette Davis received an Academy Award nomination for her role in which 1950 movie?
questions.explanation:
'All About Eve'.

	Her eighth Academy Award nomination in sixteen years.

questions.text: In Shakespeare, who was the mother of Hamlet?
questions.explanation: Gertrude.

questions.text: Where would you find 'The Bay of Plenty'?
questions.explanation: New Zealand.

questions.text: Who became the Prime Minister of Israel on 6 February 2001?
questions.explanation:
Ariel Sharon.

	Ariel Sharon ran for Prime Minister in the elections held on 6th February 2001 where he won 62.5 percent of the vote.

questions.text: How many legs does an adult butterfly have?
questions.explanation:
6.

	Caterpillars have six legs like adult butterflies but also suckers called prolegs on their long, fat bodies which help them climb up plants and get about.

questions.text: Who wrote a massive book entitled 'The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire'?
questions.explanation:
Edward Gibbon.

	This was originally published in three volumes but has since appeared in three, four, six and even twelve volumes.  And possibily any other number inbetween and beyond!

questions.text: Which of the following is a river of Poland?
questions.explanation:
Warta.

	The River Warta rises in south Poland and is about 475 miles long.

questions.text: Who provides the voice for the stout-hearted mouse 'Stuart Little' in the movie of the same name?
questions.explanation: Michael J. Fox

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the secretary bird?
questions.correct: It is an Asian bird with long legs
options: It lays its eggs in a tree nest
It has a crest of black tipped feathers hanging down behind its head
It can kill snakes by stamping on them and stabbing them with its talons
questions.explanation:
It is an Asian bird with long legs.

	The secretary bird is found in sub-Saharan Africa and gets its name from the feathers that protrude behind its head resembling quills, clerks (secretaries) used to write with.

questions.text: Which animal hunts penguins by rocking the floating chunks of ice on which the penguins are resting so they slip into the sea?
questions.explanation:
Killer whale.

	Killer whales eat fish, squid and seals. The manatee is a herbivore feeding on sea plants. The blue whale feeds on tiny shrimp-like animals called krill. Narwhals tend to eat flatfish, squid, and shrimp.

questions.text: Who is the film director of 'Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'?
questions.explanation: Peter Jackson.

questions.text: The Queen Alexandra's Birdwing butterfly is the world's largest butterfly with a wingspan of eleven inches. Where in the world can it be found?
questions.explanation:
Papua New Guinea.

	This rare butterfly is found in Southeastern Papua New Guinea

questions.text: Which famous authoress had the pseudonym of Mary Westmacott?
questions.explanation:
Agatha Christie.

	She wrote 'Absent in the Spring', 'The Burden', 'Unfinished Portrait', 'A Daughter's A Daughter', 'The Rose and the Yew Tree' and 'Giant's Bread' under this name.

questions.text: What does the spiky sea creature called the sea urchin mainly feed on?
questions.explanation:
Seaweed.

	They have a mouth with teeth and live on seaweed.

questions.text: What have all of the following all turned down : Playwrights George Bernard Shaw and J.B. Priestley, actor Alastair Sim, sculptor Henry Moore, poet T.S Eliot and author Graham Greene?
questions.explanation: Knighthoods.

questions.text: Female mosquitoes live by sucking blood from animals and can pass on the deadly disease malaria. What do male mosquitoes feed on?
questions.explanation:
Nectar.

	The female sucks blood from warm-blooded animals and many carry the parasites of diseases including malaria, yellow fever and viral encephalitis.

questions.text: Name the spider that waits on the ground or on plants and is able to change its colour to match its surroundings so that it can catch flies as they pass by?
questions.explanation: Crab spider.

questions.text: Who wrote the book 'A Tale of a Tub'?
questions.explanation:
Jonathan Swift.

	Hope you enjoyed the quiz.
